ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to apply circuits and lens theories to real life

-how to run experiments that explore electricity and magnetism, especially with regards to circuits and optics 
-the basics of the physics concepts behind such experiments
I learned a lot about circuits, electrical fields, electromagnetic induction, geometric optics, diffraction, and other physics topics.
Knowledge about principles of electricity, magnetism, optics.
It's a continuation of physics 166. We did labs that related to topics covered in physics 181 and also labs on diffraction and optics.
I learned how to apply the concepts I learned in PHYS 181 in hands-on (sort of) applications.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Probably better if it wasn't as long as it was.
Great professors

- strengths: very well organized, great and caring professors
- weaknesses: I didn't think that the PLAs were very helpful to my understanding of the material

All the professors and TAs did a great job transitioning the course virtually and over zoom. I really enjoyed doing the labs in breakout rooms with a few other people to replicate the in person experience. I also think it was beneficial how your TA and both professors switched in and out of breakout rooms so you could ask questions throughout the lab.

The course was very well-structured and organized, especially for the online format. The instructors did a great job providing students with tools to complete experiments at home with the online format.
The course was structured very well to facilitate e-learning while still teaching students how to use equipment and encouraging us to explore the scientific process.

Weaknesses: The lab handout directions are often confusing. The quizzes before each lab section don't really line up with the information in the lab handout. It's hard to get succinct answers to questions sometimes.
Strengths: Some of the experiments are pretty cool. My TA was super helpful. The labs connect to real-world experiences.
The professors are really passionate about what they teach but obviously there is always something lost in teaching a lab course online.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the professors are very engaged and want you to do your best

You probably have to take it for pre med or your major, but I think it's much better than other pre med labs (like chem). I also think it's nice to take it over the summer because it's not very stressful, and the profs are super great at organizing the labs and workload
Yes,  both if you need a physics lab but if you also are just looking for a science lab.
Yes, I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in learning about concepts of electricity, magnetism, and optics in practice.
Only if required for your major. It's okay, but not great. I liked taking it in the summer though as opposed to during the school year.
Yes, if you are deciding between different physics lab classes, I would highly recommend this one.
